title: TheVECentre.com
description: Find out how I built the website for The VECentre - a virtual venue designed with user experience in mind to reflect a live show, by artists for artists.
markdown: --- description: "Find out how I built the website for The VECentre - a virtual venue designed with user experience in mind to reflect a live show, by artists for artists." --- The VECentre by Inner Sanctum Design is a virtual venue designed to reflect a live show, by artists for artists. It was created as a replacement for in-person art exhibitions, a major revenue stream for artists, that could no longer take place due to COVID-19 restrictions. Each exhibition is bespoke and results in a 3D tour that a user can navigate around. I was requested to develop a website and implement the tour hosting. [TheVECentre.com](https://thevecentre.com) helps users find out more about The VECentre and provides an interface to access the virtual tours. The website was originally built for the Christmas 2020 tour. ## Task My task was to work alongside Inner Sanctum Design to develop the website and organise the tour hosting platform. As such, the desktop version of the website had already been designed - all I needed to do was design a mobile version and build it in a responsive manner. I made a few usability changes such as making the header reduce in height when the user scrolls (to increase screen real estate). In addition, I was required to find a provider to host the tours and make them display on a `thevecentre.com/tour` URL. ## Technical Details TheVECentre.com is predominately built using [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) and [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/). Two Next.js plugins, [next-seo](https://github.com/garmeeh/next-seo) and [next-optimized-images](https://github.com/cyrilwanner/next-optimized-images), to handle the SEO orientated properties and optimise images for different device sizes respectively. Additionally, [React Icons](https://react-icons.github.io/react-icons/) supplies any social icons, [EmailJS](https://www.emailjs.com/) powers the contact form and [Framer Motion](https://www.framer.com/motion) adds animations to the site. The tours are stored on [AWS S3](https://aws.amazon.com/s3/) in a public bucket and are displayed in iframes. As the 3D software used to build the tours creates a social image, manifest and other assets, they are loaded into the website at build time. The result is that Inner Sanctum Design are able to change tour assets and the website will automatically pick up any changes. As a separate feature, I was asked to create a "guestbook" to enable visitors to review a tour and see previous visitors comments. The data is both saved to and read from a Google Sheet using the [Google APIs](https://www.npmjs.com/package/googleapis) [The source code for TheVECentre.com is available on GitHub.](https://github.com/james-wallis/TheVECentre) [Visit TheVECentre.com](https://thevecentre.com)

The VECentre by Inner Sanctum Design is a virtual venue designed to reflect a live show, by artists for artists. It was created as a replacement for in-person art exhibitions, a major revenue stream for artists, that could no longer take place due to COVID-19 restrictions. Each exhibition is bespoke and results in a 3D tour that a user can navigate around. I was requested to develop a website and implement the tour hosting. TheVECentre.com helps users find out more about The VECentre and provides an interface to access the virtual tours. The website was originally built for the Christmas 2020 tour.

Task

My task was to work alongside Inner Sanctum Design to develop the website and organise the tour hosting platform. As such, the desktop version of the website had already been designed - all I needed to do was design a mobile version and build it in a responsive manner. I made a few usability changes such as making the header reduce in height when the user scrolls (to increase screen real estate). In addition, I was required to find a provider to host the tours and make them display on a thevecentre.com/tour URL.

Technical Details

TheVECentre.com is predominately built using Next.js and Tailwind CSS. Two Next.js plugins, next-seo and next-optimized-images, to handle the SEO orientated properties and optimise images for different device sizes respectively. Additionally, React Icons supplies any social icons, EmailJS powers the contact form and Framer Motion adds animations to the site.

The tours are stored on AWS S3 in a public bucket and are displayed in iframes. As the 3D software used to build the tours creates a social image, manifest and other assets, they are loaded into the website at build time. The result is that Inner Sanctum Design are able to change tour assets and the website will automatically pick up any changes.

As a separate feature, I was asked to create a "guestbook" to enable visitors to review a tour and see previous visitors comments. The data is both saved to and read from a Google Sheet using the Google APIs

The source code for TheVECentre.com is available on GitHub.

title: ameira.me
description: ameira.me is the personal website for Ameira Yanni, an aspiring copywriter and actor. It is built using Next.js, Tailwind CSS and uses Framer Motion for animations.
markdown: --- description: "ameira.me is the personal website for Ameira Yanni, an aspiring copywriter and actor. It is built using Next.js, Tailwind CSS and uses Framer Motion for animations." --- [ameira.me](https://ameira.me) is the personal website for Ameira Yanni, an aspiring copywriter and actor. Ameira's website acts as a platform to promote herself as a freelancer and collates all her work into a portfolio accessible to potential clients. The website design is simple and is powered by [Netlify CMS](https://www.netlifycms.org) so that Ameira is able to edit and add to her portfolio guaranteeing that it always contains her most recently completed works. [Framer Motion](https://www.framer.com/motion) is used to create the animations that [ameira.me](https://ameira.me) to life. ## Task Ameira required a website that provided a great user experience so prospective clients are able to find out more about her and her work. She further explained that the majority of her website should be her portfolio and she needed to be able to modify that section herself. Ameira and I designed the website closely to ensure these requirements were fulfilled and that the site reflects her. Once the design was agreed upon, I built the website and surprised Ameira by adding subtle animations around the website to add a little flair to an otherwise simple website. ## Technical Details Like many of my website projects, [ameira.me](https://ameira.me) is built using [Next.js](https://nextjs.org). Their dynamic routes are used to create the portfolio by creating pages based on the corresponding markdown files which store the content. To style the website I used [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com) and [Framer Motion](https://www.framer.com/motion/) to add all the animations that bring the website to life. It is hosted on GitHub Pages. Additional details: * [Remark](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark) and the [Remark-html converter](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-html) are used to convert the content from markdown to HTML, while [Gray-Matter](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/gray-matter) parses any YAML front-matter that exists in the markdown content. * [Netlify CMS](https://www.netlifycms.org) creates and modifies markdown files and uses the GitHub workflow to commit any changes back into the repository. * [Travis](https://travis-ci.org/) is used as a CI/CD pipeline to rebuild whenever a new GitHub commit is pushed. When Ameira modifies a markdown file through Netlify CMS, Travis rebuilds and deploys the updated website onto GitHub Pages. * [Jest](https://jestjs.io) and the [React Testing Library](https://testing-library.com/docs/react-testing-library/intro) are used to maintain confidence that each new build of the website is good. Its test coverage currently sits at 99% and is reported to [Codecov](http://codecov.io). [The source code for ameira.me is available on GitHub.](https://github.com/james-wallis/ameira.me) [Visit ameira.me](https://ameira.me)

  • Remark and the Remark-html converter are used to convert the content from markdown to HTML, while Gray-Matter parses any YAML front-matter that exists in the markdown content.

  • Jest and the React Testing Library are used to maintain confidence that each new build of the website is good. Its test coverage currently sits at 99% and is reported to Codecov.

title: ArtistJodi.com
description: The portfolio website for ArtistJodi. I developed artistjodi.com in 2018 and have been maintaining it ever since.
markdown: --- description: "The portfolio website for ArtistJodi. I developed artistjodi.com in 2018 and have been maintaining it ever since." --- Jodi Phillips, known as ArtistJodi, specialises in Resin and Acrylic art. Having worked as an artist for over 20 years, she has experience showcasing her art across Europe, Japan, Egypt, America, Singapore and extensively throughout the UK. After focussing on acrylic art for many years, in 2018 Jodi began a new adventure using resin to create pieces of art. With resin, Jodi is able to create art ranging from splashbacks to personalised snowboards. I was commissioned by Jodi to create an online platform that she can use to share her art with the world. Originally completed in 2018, I've been maintaining it ever since. Most recently, I added a video background to the home page to showcase Jodi's move into the virtual art world with [TheVECentre](https://thevecentre.com). ## Task Being a creative, Jodi had already designed the website layout and visuals before commissioning me. I took the designs and modified them to improve the user experience whilst keeping the important focus on her art. In addition, Jodi made it clear that she wanted the website to be fast and to be optimised for search engines (SEO). After I was given the comprehensive page designs, I set about planning and developing the website - making small artistic changes to the original design while maintaining clear communication with Jodi. ## Technical Details artistjodi.com was built using [Next.js](https://nextjs.org), a React.js framework that enables functionality such as serverside and static rendering websites. Out of the box, Next.js is incredibly fast. However, in the initial iteration of the website, the number of images used caused the website to become slow. A plugin called [next-optimized-images](https://github.com/cyrilwanner/next-optimized-images) compresses and resizes every image for different screen sizes - massively decreasing the size of each page. Another plugin, [next-seo](https://github.com/garmeeh/next-seo) is used to manage the SEO focussed parts such as page titles and descriptions. [Reactstrap (Bootstrap 4 for React.js)](https://reactstrap.github.io) is used to aid the responsive nature of the website and [styled-jsx](https://github.com/vercel/styled-jsx) for other CSS styling. [Font Awesome](https://fontawesome.com) supplies any icons that are not individually crafted by Jodi herself. [The source code for artistjodi.com is available on GitHub.](https://github.com/james-wallis/jodiphillips.com) [Visit artistjodi.com](https://artistjodi.com)

title: Wallis Family Mediation (previously Wallis Consultancy)
description: Wallis Family Mediation is a mediation company run solely by Mike Wallis. I recently rewrote its website using Next.js, Tailwind CSS and EmailJS for the contact form.
markdown: --- description: "Wallis Family Mediation is a mediation company run solely by Mike Wallis. I recently rewrote its website using Next.js, Tailwind CSS and EmailJS for the contact form." --- Wallis Family Mediation is a mediation company run solely by Mike Wallis, a retired senior banker and was a Magistrate for 20 years. Before he moved into mediation, Mike's company was known as Wallis Consultancy, a financial claims management company which he ran from his home. ## Task The original Wallis Consultancy website was made in around 2010. Mike wanted me to revamp and update his website to bring it to the standard of his competitors, and to provide a better user experience which in turn would generate him more business. After discussing design with him, it was apparent that he wanted the website to be clear, well laid out and easy to maintain. In addition, he wanted to be able to edit and create pages so that he wouldn't need to rely on me to make changes - a pain-point with his old website. I conducted some research on other competitor's websites and after receiving the consent to proceed with the design from Mike, I began work on the project. Originally I rebuilt the Wallis Consultancy website over the summer of 2016 using HTML, CSS and Bootstrap 3, but in 2020, I rewrote it from scratch once again using cutting-edge technologies such as Next.js and Tailwind CSS. I documented my process recreating Wallis Consultancy as a modern Next.js static site as [a series of articles on my blog](https://wallis.dev/blog/wallis-consultancy-rebuild-intro). ## Technical Details The website for Wallis Family Mediation is written using the React framework [Next.js](https://nextjs.org/), which enables functionality such as generating static websites, and [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/) for styling. Combining these technologies allowed me to build the website efficiently whilst maintaining a well-written React app. Each page of the website is dynamically created at build time from Markdown files using [Next.js dynamic routes and the `getStaticPaths` function](https://nextjs.org/docs/basic-features/data-fetching). In addition, I used two external Next.js plugins called [next-seo](https://github.com/garmeeh/next-seo) and [next-optimized-images](https://github.com/cyrilwanner/next-optimized-images) to ensure that the website has good SEO and all images are compressed and resized to make the page load time as fast as possible. The contact form is powered by [EmailJS](https://www.emailjs.com/) and uses reCaptcha to stop spam mail. Finally, I added [Netlify CMS](https://www.netlifycms.org/) so that Mike can make his own changes to the website. Netlify CMS uses Markdown files so it integrates seamlessly with the existing Markdown pages utilised. If you want to learn more about how I developed Wallis Consultancy, take a look at the following articles: 1. [Introducing the project](https://dev.to/jameswallis/modernising-an-existing-bootstrap-website-using-next-js-and-tailwind-css-c2g) 1. [Setting up Tailwind CSS, Google Fonts and React Icons with Next.js](https://dev.to/jameswallis/using-tailwind-css-google-fonts-and-react-icons-with-a-next-js-application-50l5) 1. [Using EmailJS to run the contact form](https://dev.to/jameswallis/using-emailjs-with-captcha-verification-in-a-next-js-application-1g1g) 1. [Adding SEO and Image Optimisation](https://dev.to/jameswallis/seo-and-image-optimization-with-next-js-23m9) 1. [Deploying a Next.js static site onto GitHub Pages](https://dev.to/jameswallis/deploying-a-next-js-app-to-github-pages-24pn) but honestly [just use Vercel](https://dev.to/jameswallis/deploying-a-next-js-project-on-vercel-in-less-than-three-minutes-with-a-custom-domain-568o) (they're both free) [The source code for Wallis Family Mediation (Wallis Consultancy) is available on GitHub.](https://github.com/james-wallis/wallisconsultancy) [Visit wallisfamilymediation.co.uk](http://wallisfamilymediation.co.uk)

In addition, he wanted to be able to edit and create pages so that he wouldn't need to rely on me to make changes - a pain-point with his old website.

I conducted some research on other competitor's websites and after receiving the consent to proceed with the design from Mike, I began work on the project. Originally I rebuilt the Wallis Consultancy website over the summer of 2016 using HTML, CSS and Bootstrap 3, but in 2020, I rewrote it from scratch once again using cutting-edge technologies such as Next.js and Tailwind CSS. I documented my process recreating Wallis Consultancy as a modern Next.js static site as a series of articles on my blog.

Technical Details

The website for Wallis Family Mediation is written using the React framework Next.js, which enables functionality such as generating static websites, and Tailwind CSS for styling. Combining these technologies allowed me to build the website efficiently whilst maintaining a well-written React app. Each page of the website is dynamically created at build time from Markdown files using Next.js dynamic routes and the getStaticPaths function. In addition, I used two external Next.js plugins called next-seo and next-optimized-images to ensure that the website has good SEO and all images are compressed and resized to make the page load time as fast as possible. The contact form is powered by EmailJS and uses reCaptcha to stop spam mail. Finally, I added Netlify CMS so that Mike can make his own changes to the website. Netlify CMS uses Markdown files so it integrates seamlessly with the existing Markdown pages utilised.

If you want to learn more about how I developed Wallis Consultancy, take a look at the following articles:

  1. Introducing the project
  2. Setting up Tailwind CSS, Google Fonts and React Icons with Next.js
  3. Using EmailJS to run the contact form
  4. Adding SEO and Image Optimisation
  5. Deploying a Next.js static site onto GitHub Pages but honestly just use Vercel (they're both free)

title: Blockbreaker
description: A Python program based on the classic Brickbreaker game created as a competition entry during my first year at university. Spoiler, I won first place!
markdown: --- description: "A Python program based on the classic Brickbreaker game created as a competition entry during my first year at university. Spoiler, I won first place!" --- During my first year at the University of Portsmouth (2015), I had the opportunity to take part in a Python programming competition. To compete, we had to extend one of two base programs into a game. At the time I had only been programming for half a semester, so it appeared to be the perfect opportunity to develop software outside of university coursework. My entry was titled "Blockbreaker", a re-implementation of the classic game Brickbreaker. The competition was a success and I won first place 🥇. ## Original brief This is an individual competition – group entries are not allowed. Use only Python and the graphics module. Don't write (object-oriented) classes and do not use non-standard libraries such as PyGame – any modules you use apart from John Zelle's `graphics.py` must be part of the standard Python 3 distribution. However, if you want to add sound, I suggest using the `winsound` module (this only works on Windows, but you can assume that we will use a Windows computer to run your program). Do not re-write the game completely – it should still involve bat(s)/ball or an android eating apples (but of course, it could do other things as well!). Keep to the spirit of the unit and the competition, and make sure that your game would not offend anyone. ## Technical Details Blockbreaker is written in Python (2.7 but works with 3) and is made up of 3 types of components - the bat, walls and the blocks themselves. It predominately uses `Lists` to keep track of game items such as blocks and score, as every block has a different value. The game is constantly calculating whether the ball has hit any component and determines whether it needs to alter the trajectory of the ball. Matching the original Brickbreaker, when a certain amount of blocks are hit, the game levels-up, increasing the ball speed and altering the colour of the blocks. For creating the Graphics, it uses [John Zelle's `graphics.py`](https://mcsp.wartburg.edu/zelle/python/graphics.py) which was used heavily in University coursework, and a requirement for the competition. It also uses built-in Python modules to read/write the high scores file, control the speed of the ball and randomise the direction of the ball when it hits a surface. The source code is [available on Github](https://github.com/james-wallis/blockbreaker). [The source code for Blockbreaker is available on GitHub.](https://github.com/james-wallis/blockbreaker)
